Posts.Title: what about Caelyx? vivo vivo

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: I feel soooo stupid and idiot. Today I found out my last chemo is not Navelbine but Caelyx... I was searching infos for the wrong chemo drug for 3 months!! I didn't find much infos about Caelyx. Are there women who take this chemo? I feel it is not very common chemo..What about the side effects? Any info will be very helpfull... Today I visited doc and she said that my lump on neck area has decreased ( I can also touch it's decressement) and that I will take a higher dose of Caelyx (:))) 40mg instead of 20 mg) every 4 weeks with Zometa. Every 15 days I wiil continue Herceptin. I used to take the three drugs every 21 days all together till now. I wish she didn't see anything bad and increased the dose because she said we have to continue for some more circles. I wish the lump will go away as soon as possible :(. I am on chemo from February 2009 with four months break. Doc also gave me a lot of usufull infos about the red hand and feet from that previous drug Xeloda. She recommende me Gedwol creme and Dactarin powder for the problematic skin areas and Alcohol Iode that the pharmacist made for nails issues. She also insisted on thaking B6. I wish someone will help with some Caelyx infos :( Have a nice day! The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: I heard that stage IV cancer is not a situation that follows the other stages (I,II,III) but a desease that is complite different from the other cancer stages. This is the opinion of a well known doc who says that it is not nesseccary to have stage I , II, and III cancer to end up with a stage IV diagnosis. Sometime it can simply occur with stage IV at the first place. Of course another opinion says that these cases are the ones that is very difficult to be diagnosed at early stages- for example if the patient doesn't find a lump or doesn't do the right tests. I always believed that cancer has to act for many years before it can be touchable, even decates. But after all the mammos that I had and finally diagnosed stage IV in one night I have to reconsider this sentence. The doc I mentioned has compared the stages with different kind of apples. If the seed is for the red apple a red apple tree will sprout. On the other side if the seed is for green ones a green apple tree will sprout. The doc says that in the same way some stage IVs are ment to develop stage IV at the first place. I whould be glad to read what is your opinion on this? The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: After finishing my chemo with Taxotere, Gemzar and Herceptin (that lasted 3 months) which have worked astonishing well ( it was kinning cancer cells so fast) I  had a pet ct that shown NED! So at that time docs stopped chemo and prescribed me Herceptin and Femara. 3-4 months later I had a reoccurance! However my second opinion doc read the pet ct yesterday and found out that pet has been done out of the area that has the reoccurance! It is the area next to the left ear! And this is the explanation for the pet results. If it had been done in this area it should have shown something , I wouldn't have stopped chemo and wouldn't suffer with reoccurance. What can I say? I had a pet ct done for my feet nails but not well done for the place of the surgery!!!!  I am just wishig that the new treatment will work like the first one..... However I keep listening about the family histories and I cannot understand if this exists only in the same kinds of cancers. And I would do anything that could prevent this to be passed to my children. I am overconcerning (I wish very very falsly) because I am thinking very much the option to get pregnant as soon as possible.  Since my mom is on chemo the first thing I think is HER and of course I wouldn't let anything disturb her tranquility! Posts.Content: vivo wrote: Ok I admit I had a very unfair ned situation. Only for 3 months..?. lol...Now I have to face the truth. I have a recurrence on the area of surgery (supraclavicular area) just down the left ear. The biopsy is positive for the lump and tommorow I will go to the hospital for further examinations to see if there is another spot in the whole body. I can't believe my calmness.:) I keep thinking that I should have had just some more time (just 1 year maybe) cancer free before recurrance.:( I haven't rest myself from the chemo (it ended on June). OK someone must be joking with me ... The doc asked me if I had rads with the previous "therapy" (my nerves - shouldn't he remember or shouldn't he have read my folder before asking?). When I told him no  he said it is great we have this arm to help now. I understood that it is the first time that the therapies act. And if I have chemo now will it worth the try since it will be the second one? I am confused. Are there any members that had so earky recurance and live for some time-years or is it a death sentence? Posts.Title: Afinitor(Everolimus) promissing vivo MJLToday

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: I went to doc today and she told me about a new potential therapy for my case. It is called Afinitor (Everolimus) ( http://www.drugdevelopment-technology.com/projects/rad001/ ) and it's effectiveness in metastatic brest cancer is promissing. I have started a mini search for Afinitor and if anyone has used it or has heard anything please let me know.. Of course I have mixed feeling on this because it seems like I am running out of chemos. On the other hand it could be better than just having chemos that will not work.  I also want to tell you I have a great improvement with my skin rash and last week went out of the hospital and returned to my daily life!!! I can walk without pain (which couln't due to hand and foot syndrom) and do everything as before the last chemo's dermatological side effect. Today I started decresing cortizone and I will take only Herceptin and Zometa until September.Then I will have to decide if I will give Afinitor a chance. I will be glad if you could help and tell me what you would choose. Have a nice day :) Many kisses from Greece! The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 12, 2009 12:49AM vivo wrote: I am trying...Not paining but still swelling. I had stoped the phyiotherapies for a while due to chemo. It might had an influenced LE increasament. From last Wednesday I will have today physiotherapy so I wish it will help a lot. It is LE due to supraclavicular lymph nodes surgery that means it is very difficult for the lymph to find a way to the body with massage. The most people in the forum have had under arm lymph nodes surgery that is a little easier for the arm to be helped with massage. In this case lymph finda the way through supraclavicular lymph nodes. A little information just for those who want to understand  LE massage functionality. Thanks a lot for your concern!

You have helped me so much and I trully believe some of you here are really wise people :) I have nape sindrom that seems to have been existing due to nape bone met. I am finishing chemo and go through tests. Afterwards I might do radiation to bone mets. I am not in pain but I have a constant nape difficulty that doesn't leav eme sleep at night. In addition to night hot flashes it makes me crazy because I cannot sleep well. Note that the last 3 years I have slleping problems due to my nape that causes me light-headedness! Is there anyone who did or does nape rads? I would appreciate a little help! Be well, feel strong! The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Topic: Good news We Have been at the hospital Post a reply heatherpalmerton heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: Hello to everyone!!! I came in to say hello and to inform you that after the first swelling arm (about a month ago) my situation got immediately better with a glove and a little masage by my daughter (she is not a practicioner but she read some things on internet just for the case)...Afterwards my arm was fine but I began doing ALL the houseworking - I think just for reaction.. So in about a week or two my arm was sweeling again (beacause of my movements) and yesterday I started physiotherapies at my previous physiotherapist. Yesterday I had massage  by hand and today by a massage machine and am feeling so wonderfull! We will buy a machine so as to use it at house- does anybody know anything about that? I am excited that I will have to go for physiotherapies instead of staying at home... Many kisses to all of you. Wish you are all well! The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: hello.everyone..so I'm on physiotherapy now vivo vivo

Posts.Content: May 7, 2009 06:58AM vivo wrote: Kira thank you for the link. I am in the beginning of physiotherapies and I know there cannot be miracles but I am planning to fight it. At the physiotherapist I met a younger woman (36 yo) who had breast cancer in both breasts and lymphedema in both arms. She was looking and feeling so miserable....We talk for a while and she was so negative about her problem. She insisted telling me that the question "why does it happened to me" is killing her all the time. I don't think it is the best way to live with. It's like leting the desease  straggle you . I also feel unhappy and alone some times but which is it the best way to live with? We HAVE TO FIGHT. We have to fight  for our loved ones and for the rest of our lives! I feel so happy to hearing for all of you that this also gives me so much strength for the rest of the road .
Posts.Title: hello.everyone..so I'm on physiotherapy now vivo vivo

Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 01:45PM vivo wrote: Girls how can I meassure myself? A therapist had meassured my hand and arm but I 'm not feeling comfortable with my glove at all. I had more swelling since the beginning and I take antibiotics for the edema. When I stop them I will have to use the glove again  but I don't feel like I have the same size. Wrapping could be an easier way? I have never wraped and never taught wrapping from my therapist.

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: Hello to all of you! The last check up shows I am stable (stable bone and supraclavicular mets). This is realy good news! My doc says I should have a pet scan so as to be sure there is nothing going on in other places. If things go well I will continue with Zometa and Herceptin alone or with a pill but no chemo!!! Great news don't you think? I hate chemo SE... Today is a positive day :) The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: good news with stability :) vivo undecided8

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2010 11:09AM vivo wrote: Thank you so so much! It is great to know someone can understand exactly what stable means... It is sometimes difficult for the healthy people to understand that this is the best option for  a stage IV. They have all the time the word "ned" in their minds and try to push us for more chemo. I have an appointment for pet scan on Wednesday and cross my fingures that it will not show anything more... The "funny" thing is that in Greece with the economical crisis, the economical minister desided that we have to pay for pet scans from this September because it is a not "needed"(one pet scan per year was free for stage ivs) . There are other tests (sacns, mammos) that can reviel problems ... Someone has to tell him that pet scan is a different test and can save lives!!! I don't think that this will save Greece from the crisis! * Edie I live in Athens and I am sure your daughter will spend a great time in Greece :)

Posts.Title: How do you say goodbye? Nanalinda konakat

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2010 05:26PM vivo wrote: I read the posts and just wanted to make a comment of my situation. I was diagnosed with atypical hyperplasia on both breasts five years ago. Doc decided to take out the ones on my right breast to test them. After they were examined and described as atypical hyperplasia doc told me not to take out the ones on the left breast cause they were not cancerous. I was never told that it could be a precancerous situation or that I had to take a closer look on my left breasts remains! After 3 years I was diagnosed with metastatic(bones) cancer from my left breast! If only I knew that I was in great danger I would had a closer look on the spots and not be sleeping awake.... The only think I know is that everyone diagnosed with atypical hyperplasia should take a closer look with an expert oncologist...Have a nice day and TAKE CARE :)

Posts.Title: 5 Years Remission of Stage 4!!! Denny123 dreamwriter

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: Hello to all my bc sisters! I am very happy for being able to come back to the forum as it has been  2-3 months since my last thread. I see a lot of you are still hanging on but it is very dark in our place.... After my last summer Femara disappointment I take (since January) Xeloda and Tyverb. This combo started with good signs and it shrunk my tumour above my left ear that is still working. However the drugs are not working since I feel the little growth. After two combos taht failed what should I expect? Should I be happy for the months that it keeped me or should I feel it was a waste of time? My doc says when a drug doesn't work we try to find another that will. Easy to be said that done! Right now  I am feeling like a guinea-pig. I cannnot imagine what the plan is but it is a very hard road to drive. Things happen in our bodies without asking us. And I need not 1 or 2 new drugs but thousants if everything is working for just 3 months. The fact that nothing lasts for long makes me very sceptical but I am feeling quite good bodily. I think it's the psychology that is down down down... The only good thing is that this forum is a huge community all around the world that I feel I can rest peacefully in it's hug.I keep you in my heart and take energy for the fight every sleepless night.  Goodnight to all of you! The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: Hello! I was diagnosed with unkown primary breast cancer with bone mets last november...In last december there has been a surgery in my left supraclavicular nodes where the metastasis had been found and I have finished the 3rd round of chemo with hercepin (I will do another 3 rounds as my docs said and after that 1 hercepin once a month). I am feeling very well with a little side effects so far. The metastasis in my supraclavicular area is not touchable any more after the 3rd round of chemo and I was told that the chemo is really working.  My doc said that the bone mets will disapear with the chemo and that nowdays early stage bone metastasis is not even noticable. Since now it is true. However, yesterday I had a swelling arm from the left elbow to the hand and my doc said I should take some antiflammatory. As I was told it must be lymphadema.. The docs didn't say anything about such a side effect. I am reading about accupuncture, sleeves or other ways to solve the problem. What should I do? Could it become worse? The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 05:09AM vivo wrote: I had to cope with the f..ing her2 status confusion in the past. I was her2+++ before the initial treatment and got hercepin. After the first failure of hercepin that I got with Femara, a second opinion doc told me that the her2 status can change in metastatic patients (suggested to do a second biopsy) and this brough a total comfusion in my decisions for the next treatment plan. Thanks god my doc told me not to do biopsy and that the fish her2 test is reliable if it shows 3 +. So I continue till today with Hercepin which I believe keeps me stable. It can also work for her2- some studies suggest. I believe that the combination with Femara is the reason that Hercepin didn't work in that period but I am not a doc.... This is what I believe though....

Posts.Title: doctor's mistakes femme janie-r

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 01:19AM vivo wrote: Well I have posted my story a lot of times, especially when I was at the beginning and trying to find out what was happening. Last September I was diagnosed with supraclavicular nodes adenocarcinoma that was mets and trying to find out the primary cause. Mammos didn't show anything so I had a quick biopsy at my parotid. The result was misdiagnosis of parotid cancer.I had a parotid and supraclavicular nodes surgery. The surgery took 9 hours to take out these and also a nerve reconstraction and two plastic surgeries and it could cost me half face paralysis, somtehing that my surgent avoid thanks God! I am stage IV and just finished 6 rounds of chemo and feel fine. The misdiagnosis could cost me disability that could kill me. Imagine being diagnosed with cancer and have a face paralysis!  I haven't done anything to find the doc of the biopsy or to sue her. I do not know what I will do in the future but for now I am occupied with my health problem and just try not to think about it.

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 04:59PM vivo wrote: Well my burn has started from little pigments on my skin and dermatologist told me that if I had started earlier a treatment it wouldn't have been so hirrible as today. I have all over my body but not on face (thanks God) but I think it is wellknown SEs of Tykerb or Xeloda. Good dermatologists give cortcosteroids to clean rash due to drugs BUT they told me that while on treatment they oncologists do not prescribe them cause it minimizes chemo. So I started corticosteroids now that I have a two months brake from chemo. And it is true that this se could mean that treatment is working. Oncologist has prescribed me cremes that help the regeneration and hydration of the skin.I have posted it somewhere here. But the best way is to ask oncologist AND dermatologist for this.
Posts.Title: Tykerb acne.. Fitztwins tooyoungtohavebc

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: *I am not sure I should post this but I don't have anyone that can understand. I am scared....I have this lump on the left part of my neck and it is very hard and quickly raising.I have to wait till Tuesday to go to hospital for further tests(MRIs etc) to find if there is any new met. I wish NO. But I am sure I will get the results in a week and the new treatment after this - maybe in 2 weeks time. There is a big delay :(  What am I going to do untill then? I am starting having really sleep problems. Waiting the lump to f.... me? What do I have to expect? I am trying to find more and more infos about new treatments. I don't want to be the idiot I was at first place. I had a terrible 9 hour surgery for parotid that was not the primary tumour. I don't want to be for second time misdiagnosed. I have two different diagnosis for er. The hospitals result says ER+ 90%  and a seconds opinions doc result says that the positivity of ER should not be evaluated (for some medical resons I cannot transalate in English). Unfortunatelly we didn't show this to the docs at first.. I am scared. The first hormonal treatment failed. Why will the next one be a success? I was told I was ned on September and now what? Of course I will be greatfull if this f.... thing starts to shrink. But doc said that I was supposed to have a recurrance after 3 years if Femara worked. I don't have the sick appearance and this may mislead even docs. From last September I had only 2 months to relax. I just want to take the new treatment soon... I am scared at night :( The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 11:15PM vivo wrote: I speak English as a foreign language and I don't know the medical term. In Greek it is called afhenico syndrom = cervical syndrom?. Maybe cervical is a better word. There is vertebra shortness in nape but before bc diagnosis I was told it was because of wrong bodys position or injury. Now docs say it  is bone mets. It is shown up in pet scan and bone ct but I didn't have any biopsy. My docs didn't leave any doupt it could be a preexisting syndrom. They say that the  vertebra shortness is due to mets. So I might have some rads in the area. I was told it could be preventative rads, too. But as you are writing , is it worth while?

Posts.Content: vivo wrote: This is my second summer with the stage IV diagnosis on my back. I remember the day of the diagosis that had cut my wings :( I prefer to count the summers because I have breaks from chemos. Last summer my daughter got married and this summer we spend our holidays at the countryside! In fact I had terrible side effects from last chemo and couldn't believe I would be able to go for swimming and for walking. But I did everything! I enjoyed the walks at the village, swimming in the sea, even dancing in the village fests!!! How can I give it up? How can we all give it up! How can docs give it up? Is there hope out there? Our body wants to live~ So just find the cure for it :) Many many kisses for you sisters. I hope everyone find a little rest from pain and sadness.... The meaning of life is not what you learn but what you teach Log in to post a reply
